headline.main: Endeavour Lands in California, Avoiding Florida Weather

results.snippet: The shuttle landed in the Mojave Desert, diverted from a planned Florida landing by low clouds and high crosswinds.
results.lead_paragraph: Jarring the Mojave Desert calm with rumbling sonic booms, the shuttle Endeavour dropped out of a cloudless blue sky and glided to a smooth landing Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base in California to close out a 16-day assembly mission for the International Space Station. Diverted from a planned landing in Florida by low clouds and high crosswinds at the Kennedy Space Center, Capt. Christopher J. Ferguson of the Navy, the shuttle commander, guided the winged orbiter to a picture-perfect touchdown on Runway 4 at 4:25 p.m. Eastern time.

results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''NASA's Black Hole Budgets,'' by Alan Stern (Op-Ed, Nov. 24):

headline.main: The Pursuit of Expansiveness Guides the Capitol's New Visitor Center

results.snippet: The new Capitol Visitor Center in Washington has more than doubled the building’s footprint and is expected to increase its annual visitors to more than three million.
results.lead_paragraph: Standing in the middle of Emancipation Hall -- the expansive lobby of the new Capitol Visitor Center that opens here on Tuesday -- you can see why the construction of this underground addition to the United States Capitol ran so heftily over its budgeted time and money. The center's 580,000 square feet cost $621 million -- more than double the planned amount. The ceremonial groundbreaking was in 2000. The hall itself is a vast 20,000-square-foot marble-floored plaza with statues standing at its sides, an eccentric collection that includes the gold-draped figure of Kamehameha I (an 18th-century Hawaiian warrior and king) and the space-suited figure of John L. Swigert Jr. (a Colorado-born astronaut on Apollo 13). A towering plaster model for the bronze Statue of Freedom that was mounted on the building's dome 145 years ago on Tuesday stands ceremoniously at the entrance to a 16,500-square-foot exhibition about the history of Congress and the Capitol.

results.abstract: "Audiences this year are going to be surprised. The range of emotions evoked by the films is going to be greater than in the past," Geoffrey Gilmore, the director of the festival, told Mr. Cieply.
results.snippet: "Audiences this year are going to be surprised. The range of emotions evoked by the films is going to be greater than in the past," Geoffrey Gilmore, the director of the festival, told Mr. Cieply.
results.lead_paragraph: The Sundance Film Festival is known for causes, for irony and for mordant comedy, but according to the Bagger's colleague Michael Cieply, this year's fare may include a lot of movies that take the emotional life of human beings as a central concern.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: AND YOU SHALL KNOW US BY THE TRAIL OF OUR VINYL (BOOK)

results.snippet: From hand-colored photographs of the holy land to paintings of outer space commissioned by NASA.
results.lead_paragraph: Before color photography, and long before the computer made colorization easy, hand-painting with oils and dyes on photographic glass plates was a common way to bring black-and-white images to life. Hand-colored photographs had an otherworldly appearance: not quite real, but close enough to suggest an exotic parallel universe. That made them perfect for travel snapshots -- especially of places already rich in fable and legend. In the Footsteps of Abraham: The Holy Land in Hand-Painted Photographs (Overlook Duckworth, $65), by Richard Hardiman and Helen Speelman, reproduces hundreds of hand-colored pictures taken during the 1920s by the Matson Photo Agency, which was run by American Christian expatriates in Jerusalem. In 1966, those expatriates -- G. Eric Matson and his wife, Edith -- gave their entire photographic collection to the Library of Congress. As the curator George S. Hobart notes in an introductory essay, Eric Matson was devoted to the prints; even years after donating them, he spent long hours ''cleaning, identifying and organizing his beloved group of photographic negatives.''

headline.main: Starting Over, With a Second Career Goal of Changing Society

results.snippet: Harvard's small but ambitious experiment for student-fellows in their 50s and 60s hopes to become a new “third stage” of university education.
results.lead_paragraph: Harvard kicked off a small but ambitious experiment this week that it hopes will become a new ''third stage'' of university education. For the student-fellows in the program, most in their 50s and early 60s, the goal is a second-act career in a new stage of life. The 14 fellows have résumés brimming with achievement -- including a former astronaut, a former senior official at the United States Agency for International Development, a physician-entrepreneur from Texas, a former public utility official from California, a former health minister from Venezuela and a former computer executive from Switzerland.

headline.kicker: BEHIND THE WHEEL | 2008 LOTUS EXIGE S 240

results.snippet: COLIN CHAPMAN, the racecar builder and founder of Lotus, followed a straightforward path to high performance: ignore the horsepower wars and focus on keeping weight low.      In 1990, a Lotus Esprit SE driven by Richard Gere made a memorable cameo in...
results.lead_paragraph: COLIN CHAPMAN, the racecar builder and founder of Lotus, followed a straightforward path to high performance: ignore the horsepower wars and focus on keeping weight low. In 1990, a Lotus Esprit SE driven by Richard Gere made a memorable cameo in ''Pretty Woman.'' That car was powered by a small turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, yet with a weight of less than 3,000 pounds it was able to reach 60 miles an hour in less than five seconds.

results.abstract: Oliver Morton Op-Ed article asserts that earthrise photograph from Apollo 8 gave people wondrous but misleading view of Earth as isolated and fragile; holds that, in truth, Earth is remarkably robust, living thing that is well-connected to cosmos beyond; drawing (M)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: EARTHRISE: HOW MAN FIRST SAW THE EARTH (BOOK)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: EARTHRISE: HOW MAN FIRST SAW THE EARTH (BOOK)>

results.snippet: A photograph of the earthrise taken on Christmas Eve 1968, provided a new perspective on the thing that all humanity shares.
results.lead_paragraph: THEY came for the Moon, and for the first three orbits it was to the Moon that the astronauts of Apollo 8 devoted their attention. Only on their fourth time round did they lift their eyes to see their home world, rising silently above the Moon's desert plains, blue and white and beautiful. When, later on that Christmas Eve in 1968, they read the opening lines of Genesis on live television, they did it with a sense of the heavens and the Earth, of the form and the void, enriched by the wonder they had seen rising into the Moon's black sky.

results.abstract: With the 50th anniversary of the 1958 N.F.L. championship game approaching, Mark Bowden, the author of "The Best Game Ever," discussed the game's legacy with The New York Times.

headline.main: The Best Game Ever: Interview With Mark Bowden

results.snippet: With the 50th anniversary of the 1958 N.F.L. championship game approaching, Mark Bowden, the author of "The Best Game Ever," discussed the game's legacy with The New York Times.
results.lead_paragraph: Mark Bowden, the author of "Black Hawk Down," chronicles the 1958 N.F.L. championship game between the Giants and the Baltimore Colts in his latest book, "The Best Game Ever" (Atlantic Monthly Press). The seesaw contest, on Dec. 28 at Yankee Stadium, included two of the league's best units: the Giants' defense, anchored by the powerful middle linebacker Sam Huff, and the Colts' offense, led by the incomparable quarterback Johnny Unitas. In all, the game featured 17 future Hall of Fame players and coaches.

results.snippet: He went out to take a casual flight and never returned.
results.lead_paragraph: He climbed Kilimanjaro, swam the English Channel, drove a Porsche in the Le Mans and raced sled dogs in the Iditarod. As a senior at Stanford he braved frigid waters to reach Alcatraz Island, unrolled a ''Beat Cal'' banner to taunt his school's rival in the coming Big Game and then swam six hours back, becoming hypothermic. These feats, however impressive, were essentially just dilettante stunts -- after the channel he was teasingly awarded a trophy for the slowest crossing of 1985 -- because though he loved all types of adventures, he excelled in a particular subset. James Stephen Fossett was an aviator, one of the greatest of the modern era. The son of a Procter & Gamble soap-production supervisor, Fossett spent the first half of his adulthood amassing millions of dollars as a commodities trader in Chicago and the second spending that fortune as he notched more than 100 world records and firsts. He holds the record for speed in a zeppelin (71.5 mph) and distance in a plane (25,766 miles without stopping). He was the first to pilot a plane around the world alone without stopping or refueling, outlasting a fuel leak, the failure of his GPS navigation unit and the loss of his emergency oxygen. In 2002, crammed for 14 days inside a capsule so small he couldn't stand up straight, Fossett completed the first solo, nonstop circuit of the globe by balloon. He'd failed on five previous tries. ''He truly was the adventurer's adventurer,'' wrote his friend and frequent expedition sponsor Sir Richard Branson. Had Fossett been born a half-century earlier, tales of his feats would have jockeyed with those of Charles Lindbergh for space on the front page. In the more jaded current era -- ''Is he merely a bored rich guy who is running out of ways to keep himself amused?'' Richard Roeper of The Chicago Sun-Times once carped -- Fossett was only moderately well known. Paradoxically, it took something that the achievement-amassing Fossett didn't do -- show up for lunch on Sept. 3, 2007 -- to make the aviator truly famous.

results.snippet: NASA has named the rocket Ares I, as in the god of war -- and its life has been a battle from the start.      Ares I is part of a new system of spacecraft being designed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to replace the nation's...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA has named the rocket Ares I, as in the god of war -- and its life has been a battle from the start. Ares I is part of a new system of spacecraft being designed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to replace the nation's aging space shuttles. The Ares I and its Orion capsule, along with a companion heavy-lift rocket known as the Ares V, are meant for travel to the Moon and beyond.
